ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Lectures were live and virtual, however, they were also recorded for later viewing purposes and for schedule flexibility.
n/a
This was a live virtual lecture but also included recorded lectures and virtual discussion sessions that were also recorded.
All lectures were also made available on Panopto for later viewing.
Recorded lecture and in-person seminar
This class was held live during the scheduled time, but it was also being recorded each time for those who were in a different time zone or wanted to refer back to the lecture.
live lectures

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I further developed my knowledge of organic chemistry. I was able to use the knowledge and skills acquired from my first semester of organic chemistry and apply it to the concepts covered in this course.  Although there was a lot of memorization required to know certain reactions and mechanisms, most of the exam content tested our ability to apply the facts to different, more challenging problems.
I learned organic chemistry 2 and a lot of chemistry in general.

I got a good understanding the material covered in ochem ii (alkynes, aromatic compounds, and a lot of carbonyl chemistry). More importantly, I feel like I learned how to think about chemistry and biochemistry.

I definitely gained the knowledge and skills from the course description from this class. It will help lay the foundation for working with organic molecules and understanding their reaction chemistry.
This class builds on knowledge from organic chemistry I to solve complex synthesis problems. It covers chapters 14 - 23 of Loudon and Parise's Organic Chemistry, 6e.
Developed a healthy habit of going to office hours. Learned more about organic chemistry
Excellent use and understanding of the basic principles of organic chemistry and how to use them in order to form complex synthesis of molecules.

This class built off of organic chem (I), so we took the reactions and concepts learned from then and applied it to the new reactions that were taught in lecture. I learned about various reactions and ways to apply them to different scenarios, adding them to the things that we had learned in first semester orgo.
very dense course covering organic chemistry

I developed the skill of logical thinking in Chemistry including using electronic arguments to explain the most reasonable outcome of a chemical reaction. I also learned how to generate starting materials from products in multiple steps using the basic reactions covered.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Organic chemistry in general is a very hard subject to understand. I feel like the structure of this course was designed in a way that facilitated my learning to the best it could be, given the circumstances of the current pandemic.
This course was a really great STEM course to be honest. A lot of STEM courses don't feel like they facilitate learning but this one was relatively great.

Overall, this course was good. The lectures were clear and interesting, and I liked the style of the course a lot. There were daily required but ungraded homework problems, which were helpful in making sure everyone kept up with the course. The midterms were pretty fair, although the major caveat is that the midterms were open note (see below) -- I imagine this course would feel a lot different otherwise. There weren't a lot of weaknesses in my opinion -- with the exception of a couple things about how the midterms were written (see below).
The class itself was difficult to follow, but that was mainly due to the difficulty of the information being taught. It did require out of lecture or textbook sources, though.

Strengths: Parr is super nice, approachable, and available to answer questions. There are short reading questions before every class, which count as participation and are helpful to redo before the exams. 
Improvements: The class textbook isn't very helpful for solving practice problems. The exams' time frame was too short; 55 minutes felt insufficient.
Instructor taught material in a very clear way. Provided many opportunities for one-on-one help. However, I felt that expectations on homework assignments were sometimes unclear.

Very good course overall, loved professor Parr and it was very well structured and organized. The only thing that could be improved is that the tests contain too many multiple choice questions where you cannot get partial credit for therefore easy mistakes can lower your grade significantly and is therefore not representative of your actual understanding of the material. For example the final exam was made of  8/11 mc questions!

The lectures were very much based on the textbook, and section reinforced both those things so that you really got the information more than once. I do wish that in the feedback we were given that the professor would give us a little bit more detail into what wasn't right about our answer, but I know that the goal is also to make us figure it out too instead of being spoonfed the answers. On psets however, I wish they were a little clearer about what exactly needed to be included in the answers because I would get points taken off for things that I didn't know were supposed to be included. I also think that the practice exams were not a good representation of what the actual midterm was going to be like.

extremely hard class even for someone who loves the material and was fairly comfortable with it. Tests were extremely challenging and unforgiving. getting two questions wrong on a given test was the difference between an A and a B-. Questions were all very abstract.

The course is hard but that is a given. I think that the live lectures could have been more informative if the powerpoints including sample questions within, rather than the professor coming up with them so that they were only accessible through the recorded zoom videos. However, the powerpoints were still helpful to study from and the upset problems provided great practice from applying concepts.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I appreciated the lectures being recorded. Although I often attended the live lectures, having the option to go back and review material I found challenging was very helpful for me.
The recorded lectures were great. I got to review them when I studied.

I cannot emphasize enough how much having the midterms be open note improved my learning in this course. In ochem I, I spent most of my studying time trying to memorize reaction conditions and mechanisms. Of course, I don't remember any of that now, and I left the course with a remarkably poor understanding of organic chemistry. In this course, I spent my study time thinking about chemistry, doing practice problems, and writing up reference sheets for use during the midterm. Although I have no illusions that in a year I will remember enamine chemistry, I feel that I'll be able to look at chemistry I see in other classes/in research and have a chance of understanding what is going on, at least in general terms; in other words, I feel like I can think about chemistry now, and I'll be able to do even once I forget the details of what I learned in this course. I feel extremely grateful for that, and there is no chance that would have happened with closed note midterms. 

I understand the downsides of having open note midterms -- for example, many students will not accordingly not study at all. I wonder if a compromise strategy would be to allow a one-page "cheat sheet" in person. That way students would be forced to make a cheat sheet, which is in it of itself studying. More importantly, the cheat sheet would not be large enough for all the material being tested, so students would have to actively choose what is important to put on that. Once classes are back in person, I think this strategy would help people learn chemistry so much better. 

During COVID, I think it's critical to have open note midterms. Otherwise, despite professors' hopes, students WILL cheat. In other courses this semester and last semester, I have observed, in case after case, "closed note midterms" on which a significant fraction of students cheat, which is incredibly unfair to those who do not. I am grateful this class had open note midterms, because that's the only fair solution.

Overall, this course adapted very, very well to COVID. The one thing is that I know an effort was made on the midterms to have primarily multiple choice questions (and fewer questions that required drawing and uploading a picture). That said, these multiple choice questions were very stressful because each question was ~10% of the grade on the midterm, so getting one wrong meant instantly a 10% drop in the grade. I'd prefer more writing questions, because there is an opportunity to show what you know and get some partial credit. Additionally, this is a tiny thing, but the multiple choice questers were often out of order (the first answer choice was often not, the second answer choice ws generally not B). This was extremely confusing.
The recorded lectures greatly helped. Due to unreliable internet or other issues, it was difficult to attend live lectures or discussion sections.
Having the lectures recorded and available on Panopto was very helpful.
Frequent office hours attendance was helpful.
Great use of the tools on zoom.
Tests could have been longer so that students had better chance of displaying all of their knowledge. each question was far too heavily graded. Homework sets were weighted too heavily.

Virtual engagement form this class greatly decreased halfway through this semester (mostly because students had checked out, no fault of Professor Parr himself) but that was mostly the nature of the semester.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would only recommend this course after taking the first introductory course to organic chemistry (I believe that is a prerequisite). The intellectual challenge was much greater than any class I've taken at Yale so far because it required you to not only memorize a bunch of different reactions but apply your knowledge from everything you've learned in organic chemsitry.

Yes. This course was really great. I was scared to take organic chemistry 2, but this one wasn't so bad. I think they organized it really well so that nothing felt rushed and I could take my time learning the material.

If you're taking it, it's probably required. That said, in this iteration of the course, I thought it was really, really good. Professor Parr was a great lecturer, and everything was clear and interesting. The lectures were a good mix of theory, synthesis, and biochemistry. The huge thing was that the midterms were open note (see above). I would imagine I might have very different feelings about the course otherwise.
I would. It is a required course if you want to look into upper level chemistry or molecular biology classes.
You usually only need to take this course if you need it for your major or if you are premed.
Yes, but only if needed. I really liked it but it's definitely a hard course. Grading-wise it's not bad at all though.

I wouldn't really unless you were required for a prereq or you are interested in learning more about organic chemistry after orgo 1. I feel like it takes a certain person to really understand the information and really get a good understanding of the material.
no, hardest class I have taken. however the professor and material were great. would only recommend to those who must take the class since I found that it was too harshly graded
Honestly, I probably would. I would let them know that they need to out in a lot of time into this semester, however.

extras.title:
CHEM 221 01
        Organic Chem of Life Processes
